properties.Name: AdvertisingCollateral
properties.Description:
An Advertising Collateral is a specific piece, article or preparation of media designed to communicate a message to an existing or potential customer, which can be used once or many times on a single media or multiple media.

Ex:
- Accordion Insert
- Ad-A-Card
- Adjacency Commercials
- Advertising Specialty
- Advertorial
- Aerial Advertising
- All-In-Family-Programming
- Audiotex
- Banner Ad
- Billboard
- Bind-In Card
- Bingo Card
- Blind Ad
- Bonus Pack
- Bounce Back Coupon
- Broadside
- Brochure
- Buckslip
- Business Letter
- Business Reply Card
- Car Card
- Card Deck
- Centerspread
- Classified Advertising
- Commercial
- Cross-Ruff Coupon
- Cut-In
- Double Truck
- Envelope Stuffer
- Flyer
- Free Standing Insert
- Gatefold
- Imprinted Product
- Infomercial
- Insert
- Internet Banner
- Island Display
- Jingle
- Jumble Display
- Kiosk
- Leave-Behind
- Lottery
- Mailgram
- Mobile Billboards
- Network TV Spot
- Newspaper Ad
- One Sheet Poster
- Outside Poster
- Package Insert
- Painted Bulletin
- Panel
- Participation Announcement
- Poster Panel
- Premium
- Preprinted Insert
- Press Release
- Radio Commercial
- Radio Spot
- Reading Notice
- Rolling Boards
- Romance Card
- Rotary Display
- Sample
- Self-Mailer
- Slogan
- Specialty Advertising
- Split 30s
- Spread
- Sweepstakes
- Tag Line
- Tear Sheet
- Testimonial
- Tradeshow
- TV Commercial
- TV Spot
- Video Advertising
- White Paper
- Zine

where:

ACCORDION INSERT
An ad inserted in a magazine, folded with an accordion-style fold.

AD-A-CARD
A perforated, tear-off coupon attached to ads in Sunday comics and supplements.

ADJACENCY COMMERCIALS
Commercial spots purchased from local television stations that generally appear during the time periods adjacent to network programs.

ADVERTISING SPECIALTY
Items used as giveaways to serve as a reminder or stimulate remembrance of a company or brand such as calendars, T-shirts, pens, key tags, and the like. Specialties are usually imprinted with a company or brand name and other identifying marks such as an address and phone number.

ADVERTORIAL
An advertisement that has the appearance of a news article or editorial, in a print publication.

AERIAL ADVERTISING
A form of outdoor advertising where messages appear in the sky in the form of banners pulled by airplanes, skywriting, and on blimps.

ALL-IN-FAMILY-PROGRAMMING
Generally refers to early fringe programs intended to attract all demographic groups, including children. 

Partridge Family and Andy Griffith are examples of All-Family programs.

AUDIOTEX
The use of the telephone and voice information services to market, advertise, promote, entertain, and inform consumers.

BANNER AD
An ad in the form of a graphic image that typically runs across a web page or is positioning in a margin or other space reserved for ads.

BILLBOARD
An announcement (usually five seconds in length) identifying an advertiser at the beginning, end, or break of a broadcast. Also, an outdoor advertising display.

BIND-IN CARD
An insert card in a magazine that is stitched in with the printed pages and often used to sells subscriptions.

BINGO CARD
A card inserted into a publication that allows readers to request information from one or more of a group of companies listed on the card.

BLIND AD
An advertisement that does not identify the advertiser, but provides a box number for replies.

BONUS PACK
Special packaging that provides consumers with extra quantity of merchandise at no extra charge over the regular price.

BOUNCE BACK COUPON
A coupon offer made to consumers as an inducement to repurchase the brand.

BROADSIDE
A promotion that is printed on a single large sheet of paper, usually on only one side of the paper, as opposed to a tabloid or other off-size newspaper.

BROCHURE
A multi-page document providing information favorable to a product, product family or service. Contents may include features, functions, benefits, support options, warranty terms, appropriate uses or implementation.

BUCKSLIP
In direct mail, one or more small inserts about the size of a dollar bill included with a letter or brochure. 

Buck slips are used to emphasize special offers, or to summarize or reiterate an  offer included in the letter/brochure.

BUSINESS LETTER
A letter in a #10 envelope (or the equivalent) with direct addressing and without any teaser copy on the envelope. This letter has the appearance of a manager to manager, one at a time, communication.

BUSINESS REPLY CARD
A card distributed with an advertising piece. The card is preprinted with the address of advertiser or its fulfillment house.  Return postage is prepaid by the advertiser. The recipient uses it to respond to an offer (which may simply be an offer to provide more  information) made by the advertiser.

CAR CARD
A poster placed in buses, subways, etc. Also called a Bus card.

CARD DECK
A collection of post card size advertisements, each promoting a different product, service, brand, organization or event, distributed as a group.

The post card is usually pre-addressed, and often postage-paid, to be mailed back to the advertiser to request more information, place an order, register for an event, etc.

Card decks are often an advertising service of magazine publishers, but may also be an independent service.

CENTERSPREAD
The two facing pages at the center of a magazine, desirable because the pages are continuous with little or no interruption at the gutter.

CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING
Advertising that runs in newspapers and magazines that generally contains text only and is arranged under subheading according to the product, service, or offering. Employment, real estate, and automotive ads are the major forms of classified advertising.

COMMERCIAL
A commercial typically lasts 90 seconds or more in length and is designed to supply information about a product or services as opposed to a specific sales message.

CROSS-RUFF COUPON
A coupon offer delivered on one product that is redeemable for the purchase of another product. 

The other product is usually one made by the same company but may involve a tie in with another manufacturer.

CUT-IN
A locally aired television commercial which mechanically replaces a network originated announcement. The premium cost paid for cut-ins is often justified in copy test situations.

DOUBLE TRUCK
A two-page spread in a print publication, where the ad runs across the middle gutter.

ENVELOPE STUFFER
A direct mail advertisement included with another mailed message (such as a bill).

FLYER
A one-page, two-sided promotional vehicle, generally 8Â½" x 11" in size.

FREE STANDING INSERT
A special coupon, subscription or advertisement that is inserted but not bound to a magazine.

GATEFOLD
A multi-page advertisement or brochure spread created by folding a double-sized page (or pages). These extended pages fold out, much like opening a gate, to reveal the entire advertisement or spread.

Double or triple-size pages, generally in magazines, that fold out into a large advertisement.

IMPRINTED PRODUCT
A promotional product, this is a product with a company logo or advertising message printed on it.

INFOMERCIAL
Television commercials that are very long, ranging from several minutes to an hour. Infomercials are designed to provide consumers with detailed information about a product or service.

INSERT
An advertisement, collection of advertisements, or other promotional matter published by an advertiser or group of advertisers, to be inserted in a magazine or newspaper. It may be bound into the publication, or be inserted without binding. See Free-standing insert, above.

INTERNET BANNER
An advertisement that is inserted into an internet message or www site URL.

ISLAND DISPLAY
A point-of-purchase display away from competitive products, typically in the middle or at the end of an aisle.

JINGLE
Songs about a product or service that usually carry the advertising theme and a simple message.

JUMBLE DISPLAY
A mixture of products or brands on a single display, such as a clearance table.

KIOSK
A free standing and usually permanent display used in outdoor advertising.

LEAVE-BEHIND
A premium left with prospective customers by a sales person, to remind them of the product or service being sold.

LOTTERY
A scheme in which making a required purchase gives a person a chance to win a prize which is awarded at random, usually through an electronic drawing. Lotteries may not be used as promotion devices under U.S. laws.

MAILGRAM
A combination telegram-letter, with the telegram transmitted to a postal facility close to the addressee and then delivered as first class mail.

MOBILE BILLBOARDS
Billboards that are towed or displayed on trucks that circulate through a target area.

NETWORK TV SPOT
Television time offered by network TV as opposed to local TV.

NEWSPAPER AD
An ad presented in a newspaper.

ONE SHEET POSTER
A vertical Poster Panel placed on transit stations or point of purchases locales such as grocery stores, convenience stores etc.)

OUTSIDE POSTER
Outdoor transit posters appearing on buses, taxis, trains, subways, and trolley cars.

PACKAGE INSERT
Separate advertising material included in merchandise packages that advertises goods or services; also referred to as Package Stuffer.

PAINTED BULLETIN
A freestanding steel or wooden structure, approximately 50' wide by 15' high, with molding around the outer edges similar to a poster panel, and including a hand painted copy message. Bulletins are generally found near highways or roofs of buildings in high traffic areas.

PANEL
This includes regular and illuminated types of outdoor advertising. A regular panel is only seen during the daytime, while an illuminated panel is seen also from dusk until dawn.

PARTICIPATION ANNOUNCEMENT
Announcements made inside the context of a program as opposed to those shown during station breaks. (2) An announcement or amount of broadcasting time which is shared by several advertisers.

POSTER PANEL
An outdoor billboard in which advertising is displayed on printed paper sheets rather than being painted. The most widely used form of outdoor advertising; standard size approximately 25' x 12' with the image printed on sections of 24 to 30 sheets.

PREMIUM
Promotional efforts designed to stimulate short-term purchasing behavior. Coupons, premiums, and samples are examples of consumer stimulants.

PREPRINTED INSERT
Advertising distributed through newspapers that is not part of the newspaper itself, but is printed by the advertiser and then taken to the newspaper itself, but is printed by the advertiser and then taken to the newspaper to be inserted.

PRESS RELEASE
Factual and interesting information released to the press to deliver information about a product, service or event to appropriate media.

RADIO COMMERCIAL
A commercial presented on the radio.

RADIO SPOT
Radio time offered by local stations.

READING NOTICE
A non-illustrated advertisement set in the type style of a publication and that gives the appearance of being editorial content.   It is marked with the abbreviation 'ADV'.

ROLLING BOARDS
Billboards that have a number of ads that rotate on a timed basis.

ROMANCE CARD
Written material that accompanies an advertising specialty, providing information about the product and its background.

ROTARY DISPLAY
Painted bulletins who face is periodically rotated to new locations.

SAMPLE
Promotional efforts designed to stimulate short-term purchasing behavior. Coupons, premiums, and samples are examples of consumer stimulants.

SELF-MAILER
A direct-mail piece in which no envelope or wrapper is required for mailing.

SLOGAN
A short, memorable advertising phrase that often appears in advertisements. For example the athletic shoe maker Nike's, "Just Do It".

SPECIALTY ADVERTISING
An advertising, sales promotion, and motivational communications medium that employs useful articles of merchandise imprinted with an advertiser's name, message, or logo.

SPLIT 30s
30-second TV spots in which the advertiser promotes two different products with two different messages during a 30-second commercial.

SPREAD
A single print ad positioned on two facing pages of a publication.

SWEEPSTAKES
A promotion whereby consumers submit their names for consideration in the drawing or selection of prizes and winners are determined purely by chance. Sweepstakes cannot require a proof of purchases as a condition for entry.

TAG LINE
A slogan or phrase that visually conveys the most important product attribute or benefit that the advertiser wishes to convey. Generally, a theme to a campaign.

TEAR SHEET
A page cut from a magazine or newspaper that is sent to the advertiser as proof of the ad insertion. Also used to check color reproduction of advertisements.

TESTIMONIAL
A statement made by a customer endorsing a product, service or company. A testimonial may be a single customer quote or it may be integrated into other marketing material such as a case study about the customer's use of a company's product or service.

TRADESHOW
A marketing message that is delivered at a tradeshow.

TRADESHOW
Advertising targeted to target audiences exposed to commercial transportation facilities, including buses, taxis, trains, elevators, trolleys, airplanes, and subways.

TV COMMERCIAL
Use of pictures in an advertisement on television.

TV SPOT
Television time offered by local stations as opposed to Network TV.

VIDEO ADVERTISING
Advertisements appearing in movie theaters and on videotapes.

WHITE PAPER
A document written in essay style that provides an in-depth discussion of an issue, technology, trend, product or process. White papers are predominantly informational rather than promotional.

ZINE
Magazines that are published online instead of in print. Often cover very specific subjects and thus have very targeted readers.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCollateralId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Marketing Communication.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCollateralName
Columns.Description: The name of the Marketing Communication.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCollateralDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Marketing Communication.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCopy
Columns.Description: The main text portion of an ad.   This is a term usually applied to print ads, and also is known as 'copy'.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingArtwork
Columns.Description: The visual components of an ad, not including the typeset text.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingVideoClip
Columns.Description: A video clip containing the advertising collateral full-motion video.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingAudioClip
Columns.Description: An audio clip containing the advertising collateral audio.

Columns.Name: MinimumFrequencyNumber
Columns.Description: Minimum number of exposures thought necessary for an advertisement to be effective.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingComprehensiveLayoutDate
Columns.Description: The completion date of a rough layout of an ad designed for presentation only, but so detailed as to appear very much like the finished ad will look.

Columns.Name: GalleyProofAvailableDate
Columns.Description: The completion date of a typeset copy of an ad or editorial material, before it is made into pages for final production.

Columns.Name: GalleyProofApprovalDate
Columns.Description: The approval date of a typeset copy of an ad or editorial material, before it is made into pages for final production.

Columns.Name: DateCreated
Columns.Description: The date that the Marketing Communication was created or approved for release.

Columns.Name: CancellationDate
Columns.Description: The final date for deleting ordered media activity.

Columns.Name: CopyrightDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Marketing Communication was copyrighted.

Columns.Name: AffirmativeDisclosureStatement
Columns.Description: A Federal Trade Commission program whereby advertisers may be required to include certain  types of information in their advertisements so consumers will be aware of all the consequences, conditions, and limitations associated with the use of the product or service.

Columns.Name: CopyrightStatement
Columns.Description: A statement regarding the right of copyright gives protection to the originator of material to prevent use without express permission or acknowledgement of the originator.

Columns.Name: MediaPlanStatement
Columns.Description: A document consisting of objectives, strategies, and tactics for reaching a target audience through various media vehicles.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCollateralTotalCostAmount
Columns.Description: The total cost of the advertising collateral.

Columns.Name: BuriedPositionAdvertisementIndicator
Columns.Description: Placing an ad between other ads in a print publication, so that readers are less likely to see it.

Columns.Name: DealerImprintIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates an ad that has the dealer's name and address included and is prepared by a national advertiser for local advertisement.

Columns.Name: ActionDeviceIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates a technique used in a marketing piece to generate a response by the reader.

Columns.Name: TargetedAdvertisementIndicator
Columns.Description: Refers to advertisements that are aimed, on the basis of demographic analysis, at one specific subsection of the market.

Columns.Name: ContinuousAdvertisingIndicator
Columns.Description: Scheduling advertisements to appear regularly, even during times when consumers are not likely to purchase the product or service, so that consumers are constantly reminded of the brand.

Columns.Name: DeliveryChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Delivery Channel.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCollateralTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Media Type.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCollateralStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Advertising Collateral Status.

Columns.Name: IsoLanguageId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an ISO Language.

Properties.Description:
An Advertising Collateral is a specific piece, article or preparation of media designed to communicate a message to an existing or potential customer, which can be used once or many times on a single media or multiple media.

Ex:
- Accordion Insert
- Ad-A-Card
- Adjacency Commercials
- Advertising Specialty
- Advertorial
- Aerial Advertising
- All-In-Family-Programming
- Audiotex
- Banner Ad
- Billboard
- Bind-In Card
- Bingo Card
- Blind Ad
- Bonus Pack
- Bounce Back Coupon
- Broadside
- Brochure
- Buckslip
- Business Letter
- Business Reply Card
- Car Card
- Card Deck
- Centerspread
- Classified Advertising
- Commercial
- Cross-Ruff Coupon
- Cut-In
- Double Truck
- Envelope Stuffer
- Flyer
- Free Standing Insert
- Gatefold
- Imprinted Product
- Infomercial
- Insert
- Internet Banner
- Island Display
- Jingle
- Jumble Display
- Kiosk
- Leave-Behind
- Lottery
- Mailgram
- Mobile Billboards
- Network TV Spot
- Newspaper Ad
- One Sheet Poster
- Outside Poster
- Package Insert
- Painted Bulletin
- Panel
- Participation Announcement
- Poster Panel
- Premium
- Preprinted Insert
- Press Release
- Radio Commercial
- Radio Spot
- Reading Notice
- Rolling Boards
- Romance Card
- Rotary Display
- Sample
- Self-Mailer
- Slogan
- Specialty Advertising
- Split 30s
- Spread
- Sweepstakes
- Tag Line
- Tear Sheet
- Testimonial
- Tradeshow
- TV Commercial
- TV Spot
- Video Advertising
- White Paper
- Zine

where:

ACCORDION INSERT
An ad inserted in a magazine, folded with an accordion-style fold.

AD-A-CARD
A perforated, tear-off coupon attached to ads in Sunday comics and supplements.

ADJACENCY COMMERCIALS
Commercial spots purchased from local television stations that generally appear during the time periods adjacent to network programs.

ADVERTISING SPECIALTY
Items used as giveaways to serve as a reminder or stimulate remembrance of a company or brand such as calendars, T-shirts, pens, key tags, and the like. Specialties are usually imprinted with a company or brand name and other identifying marks such as an address and phone number.

ADVERTORIAL
An advertisement that has the appearance of a news article or editorial, in a print publication.

AERIAL ADVERTISING
A form of outdoor advertising where messages appear in the sky in the form of banners pulled by airplanes, skywriting, and on blimps.

ALL-IN-FAMILY-PROGRAMMING
Generally refers to early fringe programs intended to attract all demographic groups, including children. 

Partridge Family and Andy Griffith are examples of All-Family programs.

AUDIOTEX
The use of the telephone and voice information services to market, advertise, promote, entertain, and inform consumers.

BANNER AD
An ad in the form of a graphic image that typically runs across a web page or is positioning in a margin or other space reserved for ads.

BILLBOARD
An announcement (usually five seconds in length) identifying an advertiser at the beginning, end, or break of a broadcast. Also, an outdoor advertising display.

BIND-IN CARD
An insert card in a magazine that is stitched in with the printed pages and often used to sells subscriptions.

BINGO CARD
A card inserted into a publication that allows readers to request information from one or more of a group of companies listed on the card.

BLIND AD
An advertisement that does not identify the advertiser, but provides a box number for replies.

BONUS PACK
Special packaging that provides consumers with extra quantity of merchandise at no extra charge over the regular price.

BOUNCE BACK COUPON
A coupon offer made to consumers as an inducement to repurchase the brand.

BROADSIDE
A promotion that is printed on a single large sheet of paper, usually on only one side of the paper, as opposed to a tabloid or other off-size newspaper.

BROCHURE
A multi-page document providing information favorable to a product, product family or service. Contents may include features, functions, benefits, support options, warranty terms, appropriate uses or implementation.

BUCKSLIP
In direct mail, one or more small inserts about the size of a dollar bill included with a letter or brochure. 

Buck slips are used to emphasize special offers, or to summarize or reiterate an  offer included in the letter/brochure.

BUSINESS LETTER
A letter in a #10 envelope (or the equivalent) with direct addressing and without any teaser copy on the envelope. This letter has the appearance of a manager to manager, one at a time, communication.

BUSINESS REPLY CARD
A card distributed with an advertising piece. The card is preprinted with the address of advertiser or its fulfillment house.  Return postage is prepaid by the advertiser. The recipient uses it to respond to an offer (which may simply be an offer to provide more  information) made by the advertiser.

CAR CARD
A poster placed in buses, subways, etc. Also called a Bus card.

CARD DECK
A collection of post card size advertisements, each promoting a different product, service, brand, organization or event, distributed as a group.

The post card is usually pre-addressed, and often postage-paid, to be mailed back to the advertiser to request more information, place an order, register for an event, etc.

Card decks are often an advertising service of magazine publishers, but may also be an independent service.

CENTERSPREAD
The two facing pages at the center of a magazine, desirable because the pages are continuous with little or no interruption at the gutter.

CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING
Advertising that runs in newspapers and magazines that generally contains text only and is arranged under subheading according to the product, service, or offering. Employment, real estate, and automotive ads are the major forms of classified advertising.

COMMERCIAL
A commercial typically lasts 90 seconds or more in length and is designed to supply information about a product or services as opposed to a specific sales message.

CROSS-RUFF COUPON
A coupon offer delivered on one product that is redeemable for the purchase of another product. 

The other product is usually one made by the same company but may involve a tie in with another manufacturer.

CUT-IN
A locally aired television commercial which mechanically replaces a network originated announcement. The premium cost paid for cut-ins is often justified in copy test situations.

DOUBLE TRUCK
A two-page spread in a print publication, where the ad runs across the middle gutter.

ENVELOPE STUFFER
A direct mail advertisement included with another mailed message (such as a bill).

FLYER
A one-page, two-sided promotional vehicle, generally 8Â½" x 11" in size.

FREE STANDING INSERT
A special coupon, subscription or advertisement that is inserted but not bound to a magazine.

GATEFOLD
A multi-page advertisement or brochure spread created by folding a double-sized page (or pages). These extended pages fold out, much like opening a gate, to reveal the entire advertisement or spread.

Double or triple-size pages, generally in magazines, that fold out into a large advertisement.

IMPRINTED PRODUCT
A promotional product, this is a product with a company logo or advertising message printed on it.

INFOMERCIAL
Television commercials that are very long, ranging from several minutes to an hour. Infomercials are designed to provide consumers with detailed information about a product or service.

INSERT
An advertisement, collection of advertisements, or other promotional matter published by an advertiser or group of advertisers, to be inserted in a magazine or newspaper. It may be bound into the publication, or be inserted without binding. See Free-standing insert, above.

INTERNET BANNER
An advertisement that is inserted into an internet message or www site URL.

ISLAND DISPLAY
A point-of-purchase display away from competitive products, typically in the middle or at the end of an aisle.

JINGLE
Songs about a product or service that usually carry the advertising theme and a simple message.

JUMBLE DISPLAY
A mixture of products or brands on a single display, such as a clearance table.

KIOSK
A free standing and usually permanent display used in outdoor advertising.

LEAVE-BEHIND
A premium left with prospective customers by a sales person, to remind them of the product or service being sold.

LOTTERY
A scheme in which making a required purchase gives a person a chance to win a prize which is awarded at random, usually through an electronic drawing. Lotteries may not be used as promotion devices under U.S. laws.

MAILGRAM
A combination telegram-letter, with the telegram transmitted to a postal facility close to the addressee and then delivered as first class mail.

MOBILE BILLBOARDS
Billboards that are towed or displayed on trucks that circulate through a target area.

NETWORK TV SPOT
Television time offered by network TV as opposed to local TV.

NEWSPAPER AD
An ad presented in a newspaper.

ONE SHEET POSTER
A vertical Poster Panel placed on transit stations or point of purchases locales such as grocery stores, convenience stores etc.)

OUTSIDE POSTER
Outdoor transit posters appearing on buses, taxis, trains, subways, and trolley cars.

PACKAGE INSERT
Separate advertising material included in merchandise packages that advertises goods or services; also referred to as Package Stuffer.

PAINTED BULLETIN
A freestanding steel or wooden structure, approximately 50' wide by 15' high, with molding around the outer edges similar to a poster panel, and including a hand painted copy message. Bulletins are generally found near highways or roofs of buildings in high traffic areas.

PANEL
This includes regular and illuminated types of outdoor advertising. A regular panel is only seen during the daytime, while an illuminated panel is seen also from dusk until dawn.

PARTICIPATION ANNOUNCEMENT
Announcements made inside the context of a program as opposed to those shown during station breaks. (2) An announcement or amount of broadcasting time which is shared by several advertisers.

POSTER PANEL
An outdoor billboard in which advertising is displayed on printed paper sheets rather than being painted. The most widely used form of outdoor advertising; standard size approximately 25' x 12' with the image printed on sections of 24 to 30 sheets.

PREMIUM
Promotional efforts designed to stimulate short-term purchasing behavior. Coupons, premiums, and samples are examples of consumer stimulants.

PREPRINTED INSERT
Advertising distributed through newspapers that is not part of the newspaper itself, but is printed by the advertiser and then taken to the newspaper itself, but is printed by the advertiser and then taken to the newspaper to be inserted.

PRESS RELEASE
Factual and interesting information released to the press to deliver information about a product, service or event to appropriate media.

RADIO COMMERCIAL
A commercial presented on the radio.

RADIO SPOT
Radio time offered by local stations.

READING NOTICE
A non-illustrated advertisement set in the type style of a publication and that gives the appearance of being editorial content.   It is marked with the abbreviation 'ADV'.

ROLLING BOARDS
Billboards that have a number of ads that rotate on a timed basis.

ROMANCE CARD
Written material that accompanies an advertising specialty, providing information about the product and its background.

ROTARY DISPLAY
Painted bulletins who face is periodically rotated to new locations.

SAMPLE
Promotional efforts designed to stimulate short-term purchasing behavior. Coupons, premiums, and samples are examples of consumer stimulants.

SELF-MAILER
A direct-mail piece in which no envelope or wrapper is required for mailing.

SLOGAN
A short, memorable advertising phrase that often appears in advertisements. For example the athletic shoe maker Nike's, "Just Do It".

SPECIALTY ADVERTISING
An advertising, sales promotion, and motivational communications medium that employs useful articles of merchandise imprinted with an advertiser's name, message, or logo.

SPLIT 30s
30-second TV spots in which the advertiser promotes two different products with two different messages during a 30-second commercial.

SPREAD
A single print ad positioned on two facing pages of a publication.

SWEEPSTAKES
A promotion whereby consumers submit their names for consideration in the drawing or selection of prizes and winners are determined purely by chance. Sweepstakes cannot require a proof of purchases as a condition for entry.

TAG LINE
A slogan or phrase that visually conveys the most important product attribute or benefit that the advertiser wishes to convey. Generally, a theme to a campaign.

TEAR SHEET
A page cut from a magazine or newspaper that is sent to the advertiser as proof of the ad insertion. Also used to check color reproduction of advertisements.

TESTIMONIAL
A statement made by a customer endorsing a product, service or company. A testimonial may be a single customer quote or it may be integrated into other marketing material such as a case study about the customer's use of a company's product or service.

TRADESHOW
A marketing message that is delivered at a tradeshow.

TRADESHOW
Advertising targeted to target audiences exposed to commercial transportation facilities, including buses, taxis, trains, elevators, trolleys, airplanes, and subways.

TV COMMERCIAL
Use of pictures in an advertisement on television.

TV SPOT
Television time offered by local stations as opposed to Network TV.

VIDEO ADVERTISING
Advertisements appearing in movie theaters and on videotapes.

WHITE PAPER
A document written in essay style that provides an in-depth discussion of an issue, technology, trend, product or process. White papers are predominantly informational rather than promotional.

ZINE
Magazines that are published online instead of in print. Often cover very specific subjects and thus have very targeted readers.
